channel.description: Recent content in Welcome to Italiano con Geoff on Italiano con Geoff

item.title: Italian Alphabet
item.description:
Italian Alphabet

The Italian alphabet has 21 letters. Here’s a breakdown with pronunciation examples, Italian-style letter names, and notes:

Letter Pronunciation Example Italian Name Notes
A as in amore a Love
B as in bello bi Beautiful
C as in cane (dog) or ciao (hello) ci Hard before A, O, U; soft before E, I
D as in donna di Woman
E as in elefante e Elephant; closed E in stressed syllables (e.g., perchÃ©), open E in unstressed ones (e.g., bene)
F as in fatto effe Done
G as in gatto (cat) or gioco (game) gi Hard before A, O, U; soft before E, I
H Silent in Italian acca Used in borrowed words like hotel
I as in isola i Island
L as in luna elle Moon
M as in mare emme Sea
N as in notte enne Night
O as in orologio o Clock; closed O in stressed syllables (e.g., osso), open O in unstressed ones (e.g., molto)
P as in pane pi Bread
Q as in quadro cu Painting
R as in rosso erre Red; rolled pronunciation is typical in Italian
S as in sole esse Sun; voiced /z/ sound often occurs between vowels (e.g., casa)
T as in tavolo ti Table
U as in uva u Grapes
V as in vino vi/vu Wine; vi or vu can be used depending on context
Z as in zebra zeta Can sound like ’ts’ in zucchero or ‘dz’ in mezzo

Foreign Letters

These letters appear in borrowed words:

item.title: Lesson 1.1: Hello and Goodbye â€“ The Essentials
item.description:
Lesson 1.1: Hello and Goodbye â€“ The Essentials ðŸ‘‹ðŸ‡®ðŸ‡¹

Greetings are the cornerstone of Italian culture. Whether youâ€™re saying ciao to a friend or buongiorno to Signora Rossi, this lesson will prepare you to make every interaction smooth and charming.

What Youâ€™ll Learn

In this lesson, youâ€™ll master:

  • Common Italian greetings and goodbyes for every time of day.
  • When to use informal versus formal language.
  • Key phrases to impress Italians with your politeness.

Italian Greetings â€“ Starting Conversations

Informal Greetings

  • Ciao (Hi/Bye): The universal casual greeting. Use it with friends, family, and people youâ€™re on a first-name basis with.
  • Ehi (Hey): For super casual and relaxed conversations.

Example Dialogue with Viktor

item.title: Lesson 2.1: How to Say Your Name
item.description:
Lesson 2.1: How to Say Your Name â€“ Introductions Made Easy ðŸ‘‹ðŸ‡®ðŸ‡¹

Knowing how to introduce yourself is a must in any language. In this lesson, youâ€™ll learn how to confidently say your name, ask others for theirs, and maybe even learn some fun cultural tidbits along the way. Ready to start? Letâ€™s dive in!

What Youâ€™ll Learn

By the end of this lesson, youâ€™ll be able to:

  • Introduce yourself in Italian.
  • Ask others for their names.
  • Use both formal and informal modes of introduction.

Essential Phrases

Informal Introductions

  • Ciao! Mi chiamo [your name]. (Hi! My name is [your name].)
  • E tu? Come ti chiami? (And you? Whatâ€™s your name?)

Example Dialogue:

Letâ€™s make sure Geoff doesnâ€™t end up in Vigevano when heâ€™s supposed to be in Padova.

item.title: Lesson 6.1: Numbers 0â€“20 â€“ The Foundation of Counting
item.description:
Lesson 6.1: Numbers 0â€“20 â€“ The Foundation of Counting ðŸ”¢

Welcome to the world of Italian numbers! In this lesson, youâ€™ll master the basics and set the stage for navigating everything from ordering one espresso (un caffÃ¨) to counting how many gelatos Geoff has eaten (spoiler: itâ€™s more than three).

What Youâ€™ll Learn

By the end of this lesson, youâ€™ll be able to:

  • Count from 0 to 20 in Italian.
  • Recognize Italian numbers in everyday situations.
  • Use numbers to impress your Italian-speaking friends (or Viktor, who loves precision).

Numbers 0â€“20

Number Italian English Pronunciation
0 Zero Zero ZEH-roh
1 Uno One OO-noh
2 Due Two DOO-eh
3 Tre Three TREH
4 Quattro Four KWAH-troh
5 Cinque Five CHEEN-kweh
6 Sei Six SEH-ee
7 Sette Seven SEHT-teh
8 Otto Eight OHT-toh
9 Nove Nine NOH-veh
10 Dieci Ten DYAY-chee
11 Undici Eleven OON-dee-chee
12 Dodici Twelve DOH-dee-chee
13 Tredici Thirteen TREH-dee-chee
14 Quattordici Fourteen KWAHT-tohr-dee-chee
15 Quindici Fifteen KWEEN-dee-chee
16 Sedici Sixteen SEH-dee-chee
17 Diciassette Seventeen DEE-chah-SEHT-teh
18 Diciotto Eighteen DEE-CHOHT-toh
19 Diciannove Nineteen DEE-chah-NOH-veh
20 Venti Twenty VEHN-tee

How It Works

  1. Key Patterns:

item.title: Lesson 7.1: Days of the Week â€“ Your Weekly Guide in Italian
item.description:
Lesson 7.1: Days of the Week â€“ Your Weekly Guide in Italian ðŸ“…

Did you know that Italians start their week on Monday? (Take that, Sunday!) In this lesson, weâ€™ll tackle the Italian days of the week so you can confidently schedule everything from gelato runs to your next chat with Viktor.

What Youâ€™ll Learn

By the end of this lesson, youâ€™ll be able to:

  • Say and recognize the days of the week in Italian.
  • Use them in sentences and questions.
  • Avoid accidentally showing up to the market on a Sunday (when itâ€™s closed).

Days of the Week

Day Italian English Pronunciation
Monday LunedÃ¬ Monday LOO-neh-dee
Tuesday MartedÃ¬ Tuesday MAR-teh-dee
Wednesday MercoledÃ¬ Wednesday MEHR-koh-leh-dee
Thursday GiovedÃ¬ Thursday JOH-veh-dee
Friday VenerdÃ¬ Friday VEH-nehr-dee
Saturday Sabato Saturday SAH-bah-toh
Sunday Domenica Sunday Doh-MEH-nee-kah

Key Phrases

  1. Che giorno Ã¨ oggi?
    (What day is it today?)

item.title: Lesson 8.1: Vowels â€“ Your Italian Foundation
item.description:
Lesson 8.1: Vowels â€“ Your Italian Foundation ðŸ…°ï¸ðŸ…¾ï¸

Italian vowels are the heart and soul of the language. Without them, youâ€™d just be mumbling consonants like a broken accordion. In this lesson, weâ€™ll dive into the magical world of A, E, I, O, U and teach you how to pronounce them with confidence.

What Youâ€™ll Learn

By the end of this lesson, youâ€™ll be able to:

  • Pronounce Italian vowels like a pro.
  • Avoid common vowel mistakes (no more confusing casa with cassa).
  • Impress Italians with your smooth sounds and melodic voice.

The Italian Vowel Chart

Vowel Pronunciation Example Word English Translation
A /a/ amore Love
E /e/ or /É›/ bene Good
I /i/ isola Island
O /o/ or /É”/ orologio Clock
U /u/ uva Grapes

Key Tips

  1. Each Vowel Has One Sound
    Unlike English, where vowels can sound like theyâ€™re having an identity crisis, Italian vowels are consistent.

item.title: Lesson 9.1: Meet the Family â€“ Names and Relationships
item.description:
Lesson 9.1: Meet the Family â€“ Names and Relationships ðŸ‘¨â€ðŸ‘©â€ðŸ‘§â€ðŸ‘¦ðŸ‡®ðŸ‡¹

In Italy, family isnâ€™t just importantâ€”itâ€™s sacred. Whether youâ€™re meeting someoneâ€™s nonna for the first time or proudly talking about your fratello, knowing how to introduce your family members (without accidentally calling your cousin a watermelon) is key to sounding like a true Italian.

What Youâ€™ll Learn

By the end of this lesson, youâ€™ll be able to:

  • Introduce your family members confidently.
  • Use the correct Italian terms for different family relationships.
  • Avoid calling your zio (uncle) a zio cane (uncle dog).

Essential Family Vocabulary

Hereâ€™s a list of the most common family members in Italian. Memorize these and youâ€™ll be ready for any family gatheringâ€”whether itâ€™s yours or someone elseâ€™s!

item.title: Lesson 3.2: CafÃ© Conversations â€“ Beyond the Basics
item.description:
Lesson 3.2: CafÃ© Conversations â€“ Beyond the Basics â˜•ðŸ—£ï¸

Once youâ€™ve mastered the art of ordering, itâ€™s time to take your cafÃ© interactions up a notch. In this lesson, youâ€™ll learn how to ask questions, respond confidently, and even engage in small talkâ€”because nothing pairs better with coffee than conversation.

What Youâ€™ll Learn

By the end of this lesson, youâ€™ll be able to:

  • Ask common cafÃ©-related questions.
  • Respond naturally to the barista or fellow patrons.
  • Engage in small talk to make your cafÃ© visits more enjoyable.

Essential Phrases

Asking Questions

  • Quanti tipi di caffÃ¨ avete? (How many types of coffee do you have?)
  • Che tipo di dolci avete oggi? (What kind of pastries do you have today?)
  • Ãˆ possibile avere il latte di soia? (Is it possible to have soy milk?)

item.title: Lesson 1.2: How to Say Farewell Without Sounding Rude
item.description:
Lesson 1.2: How to Say Farewell Without Sounding Rude ðŸ‘‹ðŸ‡®ðŸ‡¹

Saying goodbye in Italian is just as important as greeting someone. Italians have a knack for making farewells warm, polite, and sometimes as long as an opera finale! In this lesson, youâ€™ll learn how to leave any conversation with grace and charm.

What Youâ€™ll Learn

In this lesson, youâ€™ll master:

  • Key phrases for casual and formal goodbyes.
  • How to choose the right goodbye for the situation.
  • Bonus tips to avoid sounding abrupt or impolite.

Italian Farewells â€“ The Essentials

Informal Goodbyes

These are perfect for friends, family, or casual settings:

item.title: Lesson 6.2: Counting to 100 â€“ Double Digits Made Easy
item.description:
Lesson 6.2: Counting to 100 â€“ Double Digits Made Easy ðŸ”¢

Congratulations! Youâ€™ve mastered the numbers from 0 to 20. Now itâ€™s time to level up and tackle numbers 21 to 100. Whether youâ€™re counting euros, steps, or gelatos (again, no judgment), double digits are essential.

What Youâ€™ll Learn

By the end of this lesson, youâ€™ll be able to:

  • Count from 21 to 100 in Italian.
  • Use numbers for prices, quantities, and other practical applications.
  • Sound like a pro while chatting about numbers with Viktor.

Numbers from 21 to 29

Tens Italian English Pronunciation
21 Ventuno Twenty-one VEHN-too-no
22 Ventidue Twenty-two VEHN-tee-DOO-eh
23 Ventitre Twenty-three VEHN-tee-TREH
24 Ventiquattro Twenty-four VEHN-tee-KWAH-troh
25 Venticinque Twenty-five VEHN-tee-CHEEN-kweh
26 Ventisei Twenty-six VEHN-tee-SEH-ee
27 Ventisette Twenty-seven VEHN-tee-SEHT-teh
28 Ventotto Twenty-eight VEHN-TOHT-toh
29 Ventinove Twenty-nine VEHN-tee-NOH-veh

Tens and Multiples

Tens Italian English Pronunciation
30 Trenta Thirty TREHN-tah
40 Quaranta Forty KWAHR-ahn-tah
50 Cinquanta Fifty CHEEN-kwahn-tah
60 Sessanta Sixty SEHS-sahn-tah
70 Settanta Seventy SEHT-tahn-tah
80 Ottanta Eighty OHT-tahn-tah
90 Novanta Ninety NOH-vahn-tah
100 Cento One Hundred CHEN-toh

How It Works

  1. Combining Numbers: Italian numbers 21â€“99 are formed by combining the tens with the units.

In this lesson, youâ€™ll learn how to tell time like a pro (and maybe even impress Viktor at your next meetup).

What Youâ€™ll Learn

item.title: Lesson 8.2: Consonants â€“ Mastering Italian Sounds
item.description:
Lesson 8.2: Consonants â€“ Mastering Italian Sounds ðŸ…±ï¸ðŸ‡®ðŸ‡¹

If vowels are the melody of Italian, consonants are the rhythm. From the soft ciao to the dramatic gnocchi, mastering consonants will help you speak Italian like a true local. (And yes, Geoff, itâ€™s gnocchi, not guh-nok-ee.)

What Youâ€™ll Learn

By the end of this lesson, youâ€™ll be able to:

  • Pronounce tricky Italian consonants (C, G, S, Z, GL, GN).
  • Avoid common mistakes (like turning pesce into peche).
  • Sound more confident when speaking Italian words.

Consonant Guide

Consonant Pronunciation Example Word English Translation
C /k/ or /tÊƒ/ cane, ciao Dog, hello
G /g/ or /dÊ’/ gatto, giorno Cat, day
S /s/ or /z/ sole, casa Sun, house
Z /ts/ or /dz/ zucchero, mezzo Sugar, half
GL /ÊŽ/ famiglia Family
GN /É²/ gnocchi Gnocchi (yum!)

Key Tips

  1. C and G

Whether your zio (uncle) is tall, your nonna (grandma) makes the best pasta, or your cugino (cousin) is always late, youâ€™ll need the right words to paint the perfect family picture.

What Youâ€™ll Learn

item.title: Understanding 'Ne' in Italian
item.description:
Understanding “Ne” in Italian â€“ Your Secret Weapon for Sounding Like a Local ðŸ‡®ðŸ‡¹

“Ne” is like the Swiss Army knife of Italian grammarâ€”it looks small and simple, but it does a lot. It means â€œof itâ€ or â€œof themâ€ and helps avoid repetition when you’re talking about quantities. Italians love efficiency, especially when it comes to words (and making coffee).

But whoâ€™s here to help you master it? None other than Viktor, the friendly Ukrainian vendor who works at your favorite Italian market. Letâ€™s dive in!

item.title: Exercise 6.2: Double Digits Practice
item.description:
Exercise 6.2: Double Digits Practice ðŸ”¢

Itâ€™s time to put your Italian counting skills to the test! In this exercise, Geoff is trying to navigate double digits with Viktorâ€™s help (and occasional laughter). Letâ€™s see how well you can handle these numbers.

1. Fill in the Blanks â€“ Complete the Numbers

item.title: Lesson 1.3: Greetings for Special Occasions â€“ Celebrations and Holidays
item.description:
Lesson 1.3: Greetings for Special Occasions â€“ Celebrations and Holidays ðŸŽ‰ðŸŽ„

Sometimes, ciao and arrivederci just wonâ€™t cut it. From birthdays to Christmas, Italians have specific ways to greet each other during special occasions. In this lesson, youâ€™ll learn how to shine during festive moments and impress even the most traditional Signora Rossi.

What Youâ€™ll Learn

By the end of this lesson, youâ€™ll be able to:

  • Use Italian greetings for holidays, birthdays, and other celebrations.
  • Understand cultural nuances for festive occasions.
  • Confidently join in the cheer with Viktor, Geoff, and their Italian friends.

Festive Greetings

General Celebrations

  • Buon compleanno! (Happy birthday!)
  • Congratulazioni! (Congratulations!)
  • Tanti auguri! (Best wishes!)
    • Use this for birthdays, anniversaries, and general celebrations.

Example Dialogue with Viktor:

item.title: Lesson 5.3: Boutique Basics â€“ Polishing Your Shopping Skills
item.description:
Lesson 5.3: Boutique Basics â€“ Polishing Your Shopping Skills ðŸ‘—ðŸ‘œ

Shopping in Italian boutiques is like stepping into a world of elegance, charm, and occasionally high prices. Whether youâ€™re looking for the perfect leather bag, a tailored suit, or just window shopping with style, this lesson will help you polish your Italian shopping skills.

What Youâ€™ll Learn

By the end of this lesson, youâ€™ll be able to:

  • Use phrases for browsing and asking for specific items.
  • Handle questions about sizes, colors, and materials.
  • Respond confidently in any boutique situation.

Essential Phrases

Asking for Help

  • Posso dare unâ€™occhiata? (Can I take a look?)
  • Avete questa in unâ€™altra taglia/colore? (Do you have this in another size/color?)
  • Mi puÃ² aiutare a trovare [item]? (Can you help me find [item]?)

Responding and Deciding

  • Quanto costa? (How much does it cost?)
  • Mi piace, lo/la prendo. (I like it, Iâ€™ll take it.)
  • Mi dispiace, Ã¨ troppo caro/cara. (Iâ€™m sorry, itâ€™s too expensive.)

Boutique Etiquette

  1. Greet the Staff: Always start with a friendly Buongiorno! or Buonasera!
  2. Take Your Time: Italians value quality over quantityâ€”browse without rushing.
  3. Compliment the Products: Even if you donâ€™t buy, admire the craftsmanship!

Example Dialogue

Scenario: Geoff is shopping for a stylish jacket in Padova. Viktor, the boutique assistant, is ready to help.

item.title: Lesson 6.3: Dates and Times â€“ Making Numbers Practical
item.description:
Lesson 6.3: Dates and Times â€“ Making Numbers Practical ðŸ—“ï¸â°

Now that youâ€™re comfortable with numbers up to 100, letâ€™s make them useful! This lesson will teach you how to use numbers for telling time, understanding dates, and sounding like a true Italian local.

What Youâ€™ll Learn

By the end of this lesson, youâ€™ll be able to:

  • Talk about dates and days of the week.
  • Tell the time in Italian (and actually understand it!).
  • Impress Viktor when he schedules your next coffee meetup.

Dates â€“ The Basics

Days of the Week

Italian English Pronunciation
LunedÃ¬ Monday LOO-neh-dee
MartedÃ¬ Tuesday MAR-teh-dee
MercoledÃ¬ Wednesday MEHR-koh-leh-dee
GiovedÃ¬ Thursday JOH-veh-dee
VenerdÃ¬ Friday VEH-nehr-dee
Sabato Saturday SAH-bah-toh
Domenica Sunday Doh-MEH-nee-kah

Note: In Italian, the week starts with Monday, not Sunday.

item.title: Lesson 7.3: Combining Days and Times â€“ Scheduling Like a Local
item.description:
Lesson 7.3: Combining Days and Times â€“ Scheduling Like a Local ðŸ—“ï¸â°

Congratulations! Youâ€™ve learned how to talk about the days of the week and tell time. Now itâ€™s time to put them together and master the art of scheduling like a true Italian. Because letâ€™s face it: if Geoff can learn this, so can you.

What Youâ€™ll Learn

By the end of this lesson, youâ€™ll be able to:

  • Use days and times together in Italian to make plans.
  • Understand Italian scheduling phrases.
  • Confidently schedule everything from coffee dates to market trips with Viktor.

Key Phrases for Scheduling

Italian English Pronunciation
Che giorno? What day? Keh JOHR-noh?
A che ora? At what time? Ah keh OH-rah?
Domani alle otto di mattina. Tomorrow at 8 AM. Doh-MAH-nee AH-leh OHT-toh dee maht-TEE-nah.
Sabato pomeriggio. Saturday afternoon. SAH-bah-toh poh-meh-REE-joh.
Stasera alle nove. Tonight at 9 PM. Stah-SEH-rah AH-leh NOH-veh.

Example Dialogue

Scenario: Geoff and Viktor are planning their week.

item.title: Lesson 8.3: Double Trouble â€“ Navigating Double Consonants
item.description:
Lesson 8.3: Double Trouble â€“ Navigating Double Consonants ðŸ”¤âœ¨

In Italian, double consonants are not just extra lettersâ€”they change the meaning of words entirely. Get them wrong, and you might call someone pala (shovel) when you meant palla (ball). Letâ€™s save you from that awkward conversation, shall we?

What Youâ€™ll Learn

By the end of this lesson, youâ€™ll be able to:

  • Recognize and pronounce Italian double consonants.
  • Understand how they change word meanings.
  • Avoid turning nonna (grandma) into nona (ninth)â€”your Italian relatives will thank you!

Why Double Consonants Matter

item.description:

Italian wouldnâ€™t sound as passionate or dramatic without the rolled R. Whether youâ€™re ordering risotto or declaring your love with amore, rolling your Râ€™s adds that extra pizzazz. Letâ€™s make sure your Râ€™s roll as smoothly as Viktorâ€™s espresso machine!

item.title: Irregular verbs
item.description:
Irregular verbs

Verbi irregolari

1. Essere (to be)

Pronoun Present Past (Passato Prossimo) Future
io sono sono stato/a sarÃ²
tu sei sei stato/a sarai
lui/lei Ã¨ Ã¨ stato/a sarÃ 
noi siamo siamo stati/e saremo
voi siete siete stati/e sarete
loro sono sono stati/e saranno
  • Present: Sono feliceâ€¦ finchÃ© non controllo il saldo del mio conto. â€“ I am happyâ€¦ until I check my bank balance.
  • Past: Ero al lavoro, ma la mia mente era in vacanza. â€“ I was at work, but my mind was on vacation.
  • Future: SarÃ² in formaâ€¦ forseâ€¦ un giorno! â€“ I will be in shapeâ€¦ maybeâ€¦ one day!

2. Avere (to have)

Pronoun Present Past (Passato Prossimo) Future
io ho ho avuto avrÃ²
tu hai hai avuto avrai
lui/lei ha ha avuto avrÃ 
noi abbiamo abbiamo avuto avremo
voi avete avete avuto avrete
loro hanno hanno avuto avranno
  • Present: Ho fame ogni due ore come se fossi in allenamento per una maratona culinaria. â€“ Iâ€™m hungry every two hours, like Iâ€™m training for a food marathon.
  • Past: Ho avuto unâ€™idea brillanteâ€¦ peccato che fosse alle 3 di notte e ora non la ricordo piÃ¹. â€“ I had a brilliant ideaâ€¦ too bad it was at 3 a.m. and now I canâ€™t remember it.
  • Future: AvrÃ² un milione di euro… appena trovo una lampada magica. â€“ Iâ€™ll have a million euros… as soon as I find a magic lamp.

3. Andare (to go)

Pronoun Present Past (Passato Prossimo) Future
io vado sono andato/a andrÃ²
tu vai sei andato/a andrai
lui/lei va Ã¨ andato/a andrÃ 
noi andiamo siamo andati/e andremo
voi andate siete andati/e andrete
loro vanno sono andati/e andranno
  • Present: Vado in palestraâ€¦ per fare finta di allenarmi e scattare qualche selfie. â€“ Iâ€™m going to the gymâ€¦ to pretend to work out and take a few selfies.
  • Past: Sono andato al supermercatoâ€¦ e ho dimenticato quello che dovevo comprare. â€“ I went to the storeâ€¦ and forgot what I needed to buy.
  • Future: AndrÃ² a correreâ€¦ appena smette di piovere (forse tra un mese). â€“ Iâ€™ll go for a runâ€¦ as soon as it stops raining (maybe in a month).

4. Fare (to do/make)

Pronoun Present Past (Passato Prossimo) Future
io faccio ho fatto farÃ²
tu fai hai fatto farai
lui/lei fa ha fatto farÃ 
noi facciamo abbiamo fatto faremo
voi fate avete fatto farete
loro fanno hanno fatto faranno
  • Present: Faccio la lista delle cose da fare, poi faccio finta di non averla mai scritta. â€“ I make a to-do list, then pretend I never wrote it.
  • Past: Ho fatto una torta… che Ã¨ uscita dal forno come un mattoncino. â€“ I made a cake… that came out of the oven like a brick.
  • Future: FarÃ² del mio meglioâ€¦ o almeno ci penserÃ² seriamente. â€“ I will do my bestâ€¦ or at least Iâ€™ll think about it seriously.

5. Dare (to give)

Pronoun Present Past (Passato Prossimo) Future
io do ho dato darÃ²
tu dai hai dato darai
lui/lei dÃ  ha dato darÃ 
noi diamo abbiamo dato daremo
voi date avete dato darete
loro danno hanno dato daranno
  • Present: Do consigli come se fossi un guru, ma non li seguo mai io stesso. â€“ I give advice like a guru, but I never follow it myself.
  • Past: Ti ho dato lâ€™ultima fetta di pizza… ma solo perchÃ© ne avevo giÃ  mangiate quattro. â€“ I gave you the last slice of pizza… but only because Iâ€™d already had four.
  • Future: DarÃ² una mano con il trasloco… appena il mio mal di schiena sparisce. â€“ Iâ€™ll help with the moveâ€¦ as soon as my back pain disappears.

6. Stare (to stay/be)

Pronoun Present Past (Passato Prossimo) Future
io sto sono stato/a starÃ²
tu stai sei stato/a starai
lui/lei sta Ã¨ stato/a starÃ 
noi stiamo siamo stati/e staremo
voi state siete stati/e starete
loro stanno sono stati/e staranno
  • Present: Sto bene, grazieâ€¦ anche se sto cercando disperatamente il caffÃ¨. â€“ Iâ€™m well, thanksâ€¦ though Iâ€™m desperately searching for coffee.
  • Past: Siamo stati in spiaggia… e ci siamo abbronzati come gamberi. â€“ We stayed at the beach… and got sunburned like lobsters.
  • Future: StarÃ² calmoâ€¦ ma solo se nessuno tocca il mio dessert. â€“ Iâ€™ll stay calmâ€¦ but only if no one touches my dessert.

7. Venire (to come)

Pronoun Present Past (Passato Prossimo) Future
io vengo sono venuto/a verrÃ²
tu vieni sei venuto/a verrai
lui/lei viene Ã¨ venuto/a verrÃ 
noi veniamo siamo venuti/e verremo
voi venite siete venuti/e verrete
loro vengono sono venuti/e verranno
  • Present: Vieni alla festa? C’Ã¨ pizza gratis! â€“ Are you coming to the party? Thereâ€™s free pizza!
  • Past: Sono venuto alla tua riunioneâ€¦ e ho dormito per metÃ  del tempo. â€“ I came to your meetingâ€¦ and slept through half of it.
  • Future: VerrÃ² a trovartiâ€¦ non appena finisco questa maratona su Netflix. â€“ Iâ€™ll come visit youâ€¦ as soon as I finish this Netflix marathon.

8. Dire (to say/tell)

Pronoun Present Past (Passato Prossimo) Future
io dico ho detto dirÃ²
tu dici hai detto dirai
lui/lei dice ha detto dirÃ 
noi diciamo abbiamo detto diremo
voi dite avete detto direte
loro dicono hanno detto diranno
  • Present: Dico sempre â€œdomani inizio la dietaâ€â€¦ ma domani non arriva mai. â€“ I always say â€œIâ€™ll start the diet tomorrowâ€â€¦ but tomorrow never comes.
  • Past: Mi hai detto che sarebbe stato facile… non so se ridere o piangere. â€“ You told me it would be easyâ€¦ I donâ€™t know whether to laugh or cry.
  • Future: Ti dirÃ² un segretoâ€¦ appena lo scoprirÃ² anchâ€™io. â€“ Iâ€™ll tell you a secretâ€¦ as soon as I figure it out myself.

9. Sapere (to know)

Pronoun Present Past (Passato Prossimo) Future
io so ho saputo saprÃ²
tu sai hai saputo saprai
lui/lei sa ha saputo saprÃ 
noi sappiamo abbiamo saputo sapremo
voi sapete avete saputo saprete
loro sanno hanno saputo sapranno
  • Present: So tuttoâ€¦ soprattutto quando si tratta di serie TV. â€“ I know everythingâ€¦ especially when itâ€™s about TV series.
  • Past: Non ho saputo rispondereâ€¦ ma ho annuito come se capissi tutto. â€“ I didnâ€™t know the answerâ€¦ but I nodded as if I understood everything.
  • Future: SaprÃ² cosa fareâ€¦ appena Google me lo dirÃ . â€“ Iâ€™ll know what to doâ€¦ as soon as Google tells me.

10. Uscire (to go out)

Pronoun Present Past (Passato Prossimo) Future
io esco sono uscito/a uscirÃ²
tu esci sei uscito/a uscirai
lui/lei esce Ã¨ uscito/a uscirÃ 
noi usciamo siamo usciti/e usciremo
voi uscite siete usciti/e uscirete
loro escono sono usciti/e usciranno
  • Present: Usciamo stasera? O rimaniamo a casa a guardare serie? â€“ Are we going out tonight? Or staying home to binge-watch series?
  • Past: Sono uscito ieriâ€¦ e oggi non mi sento piÃ¹ le gambe. â€“ I went out yesterdayâ€¦ and today I canâ€™t feel my legs.
  • Future: UscirÃ² piÃ¹ tardiâ€¦ se riesco a trovare la mia motivazione. â€“ Iâ€™ll go out laterâ€¦ if I can find my motivation.

11. Potere (to be able/can)

Pronoun Present Past (Passato Prossimo) Future
io posso ho potuto potrÃ²
tu puoi hai potuto potrai
lui/lei puÃ² ha potuto potrÃ 
noi possiamo abbiamo potuto potremo
voi potete avete potuto potrete
loro possono hanno potuto potranno
  • Present: Posso mangiare tutta la pizza? Certo, se non mi guardi male! â€“ Can I eat all the pizza? Sure, if you donâ€™t give me the side-eye!
  • Past: Non ho potuto resistereâ€¦ e ho comprato quellâ€™ennesimo gadget inutile. â€“ I couldnâ€™t resistâ€¦ and bought yet another useless gadget.
  • Future: PotrÃ² finalmente dormireâ€¦ il giorno in cui non avrÃ² sveglie. â€“ Iâ€™ll finally be able to sleepâ€¦ the day I have no alarms.

12. Volere (to want)

Pronoun Present Past (Passato Prossimo) Future
io voglio ho voluto vorrÃ²
tu vuoi hai voluto vorrai
lui/lei vuole ha voluto vorrÃ 
noi vogliamo abbiamo voluto vorremo
voi volete avete voluto vorrete
loro vogliono hanno voluto vorranno
  • Present: Voglio un gelato… ma la bilancia non sarÃ  dâ€™accordo. â€“ I want ice cream… but the scale wonâ€™t agree.
  • Past: Ho voluto essere produttivoâ€¦ ma il divano ha avuto la meglio. â€“ I wanted to be productiveâ€¦ but the couch won.
  • Future: VorrÃ² delle ferieâ€¦ subito dopo le ferie. â€“ Iâ€™ll want a vacationâ€¦ right after my vacation.

13. Dovere (to have/must)

Pronoun Present Past (Passato Prossimo) Future
io devo ho dovuto dovrÃ²
tu devi hai dovuto dovrai
lui/lei deve ha dovuto dovrÃ 
noi dobbiamo abbiamo dovuto dovremo
voi dovete avete dovuto dovrete
loro devono hanno dovuto dovranno
  • Present: Devo andare in palestraâ€¦ ma il mio letto dice il contrario. â€“ I have to go to the gymâ€¦ but my bed says otherwise.
  • Past: Abbiamo dovuto fare le pulizieâ€¦ ma solo perchÃ© aspettavamo ospiti. â€“ We had to cleanâ€¦ but only because guests were coming over.
  • Future: DovrÃ² fare la spesaâ€¦ prima o poi, se voglio cenare. â€“ Iâ€™ll have to go grocery shoppingâ€¦ sooner or later, if I want dinner.

Why Do We Use ‘ho’ and ‘sono’ in the Past Tense?

Learning Italian grammar can feel like cooking pasta al dente: a bit of pressure, but worth it! If youâ€™re wondering why Italians switch between “ho” and “sono” in the past tense, letâ€™s dive in (without overcooking it).
